questions.question_text: A large organization needs to report risk at all levels for a new centralized virtualization project to reduce cost and improve performance. Which of the following would MOST effectively represent the overall risk of the project to senior management?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Risk heat map.

A risk heat map visually represents risks in a way that helps senior management quickly understand the magnitude and significance of risks associated with the project. It typically uses color coding to indicate the level of risk, with red typically representing high-risk areas and green representing low-risk areas. This visual representation allows senior management to identify critical areas of concern and allocate resources and attention accordingly.

Selected Answer: A

magnitude

Selected Answer: B
Going with Centralized Risk Register. The 7th edition review manual's section on risk maps does not imply they would be good for covering risk at all levels. The question focusing on a large organization and a need to understand all levels leaves B the most likely answer.

A. Risk heat map would MOST effectively represent the overall risk of the centralized virtualization project to senior management.

A risk heat map provides a visual representation of risks based on their likelihood and impact, allowing senior management to quickly and easily understand the overall risk profile of the project. This approach can help senior management identify the areas of the project that require the most attention and focus their efforts on managing the most significant risks.

While a centralized risk register (Option B) can provide a comprehensive view of the project's risks, it may not be as effective as a risk heat map in conveying the overall risk profile of the project to senior management.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be the GREATEST challenge when implementing a corporate risk framework for a global organization?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A standardized risk taxonomy ensures a common language across all business units, but aligning different risk definitions, classifications, and tolerance levels across regions is highly challenging.

Selected Answer: B
B. Risk taxonomy
For a global organization, developing a unified risk taxonomy that is consistent across diverse business units, regions, and cultures can be particularly challenging. Different regions might have varying definitions of risk, diverse risk priorities, or different terminologies. Establishing a consistent language and structure for risk (i.e., a risk taxonomy) that is universally understood and applied across the organization is crucial for effective risk management on a global scale.
